titleStmt.title: The treaty and articles of agreement between the Estates of Holland, the Prince of Orange, and magistrates of Amsterdam. With an exact narrative of the chief passages and proceedings at the besieging of the said town by the Prince of Orange; the manner of raising their batteries, and 300 piece of ordnance mounted against the Prince's army. Also the discovery of a great plot and designe aagainst [sic] the towns of Delph. Dort, Medembleck, Harlen and Hoarn. With the Prince's seizing on several Lords of Holland, and commiting them prisoners to Lovestein Castle.
titleStmt.author: United Provinces of the Netherlands. Staten Generaal.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Amsterdam (Netherlands) -- History -- Siege, 1650 -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: THE TREATY AND ARTICLES OF AGREEMENT BETWEEN The EÅ¿tates of Holland, the Prince of Orange, and MagiÅ¿trates of AMSTERDAM.

WITH An exact Narrative of the chief PaÅ¿Å¿ages and Proceedings at the beÅ¿ieging of the Å¿aid Town by the Prince of Orange; the manner of raiÅ¿ing their Batteries, and 300 Piece of Ordnance mounted againÅ¿t the Prince's Army.

ALSO The diÅ¿covery of a great Plot and DeÅ¿igne a-againÅ¿t the Towns of Delph. Dort, Medembleck, Harlen and Hoarn. With the Prince's Å¿eizing on Å¿everal Lords of Holland, and commiting them priÅ¿oners to LoveÅ¿tein CaÅ¿tle.
London, Printed by J. Clowes, over againÅ¿t the lewer-Pump in Grub-Å¿treet. 1650.

div.head: A LETTER FROM ROTTERDAM.
div.p:
THe newes we have at preÅ¿ent here, I Å¿hall impart to you. (as far as time will give leave.) About 2 or 3 months Å¿ince, the EÅ¿tates of Holland had Å¿ome difference with the Prince of Orange, about caÅ¿ â¢â¢ ering or disbanding of forces, they deÅ¿iring that they might eaÅ¿e the people of their taxes, as the ot â¢â¢ r Provinces have (they alone paying about 60 g. per cent. whenas all the other 6 Provinces pay but the remaining 40 between them all) they complained much of their Officers, that they abuÅ¿ed them by falÅ¿e MuÅ¿tering their
Souldiers; for if they were allowed 60 in a Company, they would not keep above 30. and the reaÅ¿on was (the Capt. Å¿ay) for want of current payment, being forct to make uÅ¿e of men called Soliciteurs to furniÅ¿h them with Money, who deduct above 20 or 25 Per. cent. for their disburÅ¿ment. Now the EÅ¿tates of Holland indeed, did not Å¿o much deÅ¿ire to disband any Soldiers; but that the Companies being Å¿o Å¿mall, they might disband Å¿ome Officers, and keep up all the Souldiers, and by caÅ¿hiering of thoÅ¿e Soliciteurs, and by managing the buÅ¿ineÅ¿s well in paying the Souldiers currently themÅ¿elves, they would Å¿ave 100000 pound Per Annum. The major Vote in the States General was, to Å¿ide with the Prince, the one having a Brother a Soliciteur, a CouÅ¿en perhaps a Col. another friend a Capt. &c. and they petitioning them and the P. of Orange continually to be kept up, and not disbanded: reÅ¿olved they would live and dy with each other, (now you muÅ¿t take notice that all the States General did not give their Votes to this, but the Major part; for 2 or 3 Provinces have Å¿ince proteÅ¿ted againÅ¿t their proceedings) and then the EngliÅ¿h CavelieriÅ¿h Col. and Capt. under his Command, with thoÅ¿e of the States General, (that had voted they Å¿hould not be disbanded) tickled him in the ear with many Å¿trang things that they would do for him, and to curb Holland by the Å¿word, and to make him a Soveraign of theÅ¿e Countries, and certainly to effect this, he wanted none of Charles Stuarts Councel, nor of his mother Mall neither, for the EngliÅ¿h Malignants here did report tha â¢ their deÅ¿ign was a month Å¿ince juÅ¿t as hereafter related. On the 20. June or there abouts, the Prince with his Colonels Capt. and other Officers, moÅ¿t EngliÅ¿h
Malignants, with Å¿ome CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners of the EÅ¿tates General, went about to all the towns in Holland, where the Prince was nobly entertained as their Gen. but at AmÅ¿terdam, Delph, Dort, Medemcleck, Harlen & Hoarne, they would not give them audience in their publick Common-Councels, (in their Towns) not acknowledging the CommiÅ¿Å¿ions they came withall, Å¿o they gave them no content; the Prince with the reÅ¿t returned again to the Hague, where they were all as it were mad that they could not obtain their ends; remaining there, they Å¿tudyed day and night of a way how to obtain that by force, which (as they thought) could not be had with Love: So on Saturday laÅ¿t (being the 30. alias 20. July) the P. of Orange Å¿eized on 6 Lords of Holland as they were in full Councel, viz. one of Dort, one of Delph, two of Harlen, one of Horn, two of Medembleck and thoÅ¿e two of AmÅ¿terdam eÅ¿caped; they were the next day all carried to a CaÅ¿tle near Gorcom called LoveÅ¿tein, being chiefly for a priÅ¿on, were none but traytors are put in. That Å¿ame day viz. the 30. alias 20. July, the Prince gave CommiÅ¿Å¿ion for his Army to march out of GariÅ¿on to AmÅ¿terdam; where on Saturday laÅ¿t in the morning, appeared 2000 horÅ¿e and 1000 foot; but being diÅ¿covered by the Hamborough PoÅ¿t, the Lords of the Town were acquainted therewith, and command was given, the Gates Å¿hould be Å¿hut, and the Magazine being opened, about 300 pieces of Ordnance, was by the boys and labourers in the Å¿treets drag'd up to the wals and Sconces, and Drums beat for the trained bands to be preÅ¿ently in Arms, which was effected: as alÅ¿o the Souldiery that belongs to the Town, being about 5 or 600 were alÅ¿o in Arms, & kept Å¿trict watch both at gates &
walls, the Å¿ame day a Company of their Soldiers with Carpenters went out, and cut down all draw Bridges, and got men of war in great number, to lye from Texel to the River Tye, for fear of forces to come in by Sea (as was reported) from Zealand, the mean time drums beat for to liÅ¿t Soldiers in the Town, and gave 15 Å¿tivers a day, and in 2 days time had above 12000 Souldiers in pay, on the Lords day they in the Town Å¿et open their Å¿luces, and drowned all the land round about, Å¿o that the Princes Å¿ouldiery was forc't to keep on the bank-Å¿ides, which were high; the mean time moÅ¿t part of all his Army came down thither both horÅ¿e & Foot, and laid Å¿iege to it; and in 2 or 3 places began to make works againÅ¿t it. Take notice that till the Lords day noone he himÅ¿elf remained in the Hague, and knew no otherwiÅ¿e but his men were got into AmÅ¿terdam: but when he heard the contrary, he was mad and ready to tare his hair off his head, and Å¿eeing himÅ¿elf thus deprived of his hopes in the deÅ¿ign, he (like a Lyon robbed of her whelps) did Å¿o take on, and immediatly in perÅ¿on went to the leaguer; where in a rage, as before mentioned, he began to raiÅ¿e works, but to no purpoÅ¿e. The mean time, this town of Rotterdam Å¿tood nutral, and we expected every hour that Å¿ome of his Souldiers would come and quarter upon us, but did not, and Dort, Delph, Leyden, Harlen and other Townes Å¿hut their Gates, and were in Arms. On Munday and TueÅ¿day the EÅ¿tates of Holland (conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of one or two men out of each Town) met, and reÅ¿olved to Å¿end for him home, and the States Gen. Å¿eeing his deÅ¿ign broke, they moÅ¿t of them fell off from him, and both Å¿ent a Committee to him to Treat, and thoÅ¿e alÅ¿o of AmÅ¿terdam Å¿ent to him, and on WedneÅ¿day laÅ¿t they were agreed as followeth.

That the Army Å¿hall again march to their quarters, and the town Å¿hall not be moleÅ¿ted; but that trading may be free, and thoÅ¿e that were the cauÅ¿ers of this trouble, Å¿hall give an account for it afterward; which Å¿hall be diÅ¿puted at the next meeting at the HAGUE.

It is my opinion, that though the buÅ¿ineÅ¿s is appeaÅ¿ed for the preÅ¿ent; yet Å¿ome heads will fly for it, and the P. himÅ¿elf, if his head remains on his Å¿houlders, it will be well: however they all Å¿ay, they will take a great part of his power from him. Certainly if he had taken AMSTERDAM, he would have made himÅ¿elf Soveraign of theÅ¿e Countries, to have made Å¿laves of theÅ¿e people of Holland; His intentions were to have Å¿eized upon the Banck there, and the Å¿tock of the town, which is many millions. The people in general hate this odious deÅ¿ign of his, and as well MagiÅ¿trates as people Å¿ay plainly, they may thank his brother Charls for this, and had he obtained his deÅ¿i â¢ e, he had moÅ¿t aÅ¿Å¿uredly curb'd the EÅ¿tates of Holland for their friendly aÅ¿siÅ¿tance or correÅ¿pondency, and would have bin very able to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t his Brother; but we may Å¿ee much of God in this buÅ¿ineÅ¿s, and I hope
theÅ¿e Countries will make a faÅ¿ter union with England then ever yet they have done. The EngliÅ¿h Malignants here, are Å¿ad at this buÅ¿ineÅ¿s, for they were in hopes, and were confidently aÅ¿Å¿ured had this deÅ¿ign gone on, that their deÅ¿ign alÅ¿o would be promoted by it. I have thus as near as I can, given you the relation of this buÅ¿ineÅ¿s; for any other particulars, I refer you to AmÅ¿terdam Letters, Vale.

If the troubles had continued, I had Å¿ent my wife & child to London per this paÅ¿Å¿age now a going, per whom alÅ¿o many families of our EngliÅ¿h would have gone, all things being packed up in a readineÅ¿s; but now we Å¿hall wait to Å¿ee what God Å¿hall farther do with us. Some of your Company removed their cloth to Zealand, for it was not here without danger; For a great many Companies of Souldiers were quartered at the Hague and we did expect them or others here, and the Malignants would have been favoured, but the better party burthened.
The Lord of Dort that was taken priÅ¿oner (by name De Witt) is dead, its thought poyÅ¿oned.
